./.title: Introduction
./.body:
Introduction
This is a book describing our ongoing project12 on MPC version of MACI. This text is preliminary, and lacks proofs and other crucial details; hopefully at some point it becomes more rigid.
Lev Soukhanov, Yaroslav Rebenko

1. Supported by a grant from PSE / Ethereum Foundation. ↩


2. First author would also like to express his gratitude to Lúcás Meier for useful discussions on oblivious permutations, to Stanislaw Baranski for pointing author to this topic, and to Barry White Hat for suggesting this research project. ↩

chapter-1-overview/protocol-overview.htm.title: Protocol overview
chapter-1-overview/protocol-overview.htm.body:
Protocol overview
Stub
Refer to the decription of the main protocol for now.

chapter-2-preliminaries/SUMMARY.html.title: Preliminaries
chapter-2-preliminaries/SUMMARY.html.body:
Chapter2 - Preliminaries
Stub
In this chapter, we overview commonly known techniques in MPC.
We are also planning to write down some treatment of collaborative SNARKs, but currently it is not done.

chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/SUMMARY.html.title: MPC
chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/SUMMARY.html.body:
Multi-party computation
In this section, we describe the basics of multi-party computation. It is not strictly necessary to understand the follow-up, but is recommended.
It is also not certain that all constructions from this part will be used in the end (in particular, there are more efficient bit decomposition techniques, namely eDaBits, coming with their unique tradeoff).

chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/common-const.title: Common constructions
chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/common-const.body:
Common constructions
We present a few useful constructions from the literature and folklore, which we will use throughout the text.
The exposition for most of these very closely follows https://www.iacr.org/archive/pkc2007/44500343/44500343.pdf, with some minor differences.
Sharing over elliptic curves is folklore, but our view is largely influenced by https://eprint.iacr.org/2021/1530. These are simple primitives - and more elaborate subprotocols are left for the next chapter.

chapter-2-preliminaries/collab.html.title: Collaborative SNARKs
chapter-2-preliminaries/collab.html.body:
Collaborative SNARKs
Stub
Collaborative SNARKs is an (quite an) universal way of turning an arithmetic MPC protocol into so called "auditable MPC" - i.e. the computation scheme in which the correctness is guaranteed with a ZK-proof, even in case of compromise of MPC. It is described in this recent work, we will briefly state their properties.

Collaborative SNARK takes as an input a shared witness - i.e. the witness vector to the computation, linearly shared between parties. So, an arithmetic MPC is a natural fit for it (because it, roughly, produces shared witness as its computation trace).
This witness is then treated (in MPC) to produce a proof (efficiently - for schemes relying mostly on linear operations and few pairings, notably Groth16 and PlonK). The performance at this stage almost does not degrade compared to a single party computation.
Naturally, this also turns some semi-honest computation schemes into maliciously secure, because the proof will fail. This, however, has exceptions and limitations - notably, when deviation from the protocol might break privacy without breaking correctness. This is, in particular, important for the oblivious random permuation case.

chapter-3-subprotocols/SUMMARY.html.title: Subprotocols
chapter-3-subprotocols/SUMMARY.html.body:
Chapter 3 - Subprotocols
Stub
In this chapter, we discuss our main tools at achieving the goal - most importantly, oblivious permutations.

chapter-4-protocol/SUMMARY.html.title: Main protocol
chapter-4-protocol/SUMMARY.html.body:
Chapter 4 - Main Protocol
Stub
In this chapter, we discuss the main protocol.

chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/common-const.title: Unbounded fan-in OR
chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/common-const.body:
Unbounded fan-in OR
Source paper suggests some elaborate argument, but actually we can just negate every bit (xi→1−xix_i \rightarrow 1-x_ixi​→1−xi​), multiply them and negate the answer back, so we don't really see what's the point. It is also much faster.
Prefix-or is computed similarly, using running product construction.

chapter-3-subprotocols/lookup.html.title: Lookup witness generation
chapter-3-subprotocols/lookup.html.body:
Lookup
In this part, we describe how to produce a witness to the lookup argument described here.
We have a pair of arrays, A and S of the same length m, in our case S can be assumed to be public and already sorted, and A is a shared array, which is known to be a subset of S (with repetitions). The witness consists of a new pair of arrays, _A, _S, satisfing the following condition: either _A[i] == _S[i], or _A[i] == _A[i-1]. The second condition can not hold for i == 0.
The arrays also are constrained by requirement that A is a permutation of _A, and S is a permutation of _S.
The non-MPC algorithm does the following:

Sort A, this will be _A. Call an index i "initial" if either i == 0, or _A[i] != _A[i-1]. 
For each initial element, find the corresponding j such that _A[i] = S[j], and set _S[i] = S[j].
Fill in the rest of values.

Searching for elements in MPC is not very efficient, so we use a slightly different strategy:

Consider a disjoint union T=A⊔ST = A \sqcup ST=A⊔S (we will add an additional parameter to remember from which array an element came from, so T[i].value represents the actual value, and T[i].ext is either 0 or 1). Sort in place by value.
Introduce a new bit flag: T[i].paired, which is set as (T[i].ext == 1 & T[i-1].ext == 0) | (T[i].ext == 0 & T[i+1].ext == 1).
Sort in place by ext > 1-paired, strip off additional introduced fields.
Create a new array of tuples pairs[i] = (T[i], T[m+i]).
Sort this array by the first element of the tuple in place, set (_A[i], _S[i]) = pairs[i].

Why this works:
First, we sort by value, so obtain the batches of the same value coming from A, intercepted by increasing values coming from S. The field paired is set to 1 exactly for one element from A and corresponding element from S (also, in this phase we could check whether lookup is incorrect if we wanted, which amounts to a situation where the neighboring elements with ext == 0 have different values).
Now, we order by ext, splitting the arrays back and there move the elements of paired == 1 kind to the left of their respective halves. Upon pairing, and sorting by the first element of the tuple, each paired element of A becomes first in a batch of the elements of equal value (because the sort was stable).

chapter-1-overview/problem-statement.htm.title: Problem statement
chapter-1-overview/problem-statement.htm.body:
Problem statement
Stub
MACI, minimal anti-collusion infrastructure is a voting system, suggested here: https://ethresear.ch/t/minimal-anti-collusion-infrastructure/5413 by Vitalik Buterin, and implemented here: https://github.com/privacy-scaling-explorations/maci.
We are aiming to improve it by swapping a singular server for an MPC in such a way that user privacy could be broken only by collusion of parties in MPC.
Other desired properties - non-coercibility and auditability should still hold.
We mainly consider some simmilar settings:

Third party is trying to force user into voting as they please.
Third party is trying to waste user's voice.
Third party is trying to buy user's voice.
User themselves is trying to sell their voice.

We assume that a third party can force user into some sort of a MPC protocol.
Some examples of possible attacks:

Third pary forses user to engage in a 2-party protocol in which user will sign a transaction with unknown content with their private key.
If third party can prove that there are at least kkk transactions from the user published on a blockchain, they can force user to provide third party with contents of kkk different transactions, then use 1.1.1. and check if there are such blocks on blockchain.

chapter-4-protocol/server-zk.html.title: Witness generation
chapter-4-protocol/server-zk.html.body:
Witness generation
Here, we describe the circuit for the external audit, and the process of witness generation. The baseline is the following:

Use PlonKish arithmetization.
Follow the MPC process, every time the sorting is done, constrain the new array to be a permutation of a previous array, and to be sorted (which is a local check).
For comparisons, ignore bit decompositions produced by MPC and use a separate lookup argument. Producing lookup argument witness (say, using an argument from halo2) is not exactly trivial, but can be done.

The size of the circuit can be done ∼log⁡(m)\sim \log(m)∼log(m) smaller by doing some additional work in MPC (one could, theoretically, skip the whole 2nd phase, by just requiring that the non-nullified votes in phase 111 are ordered in a way that respects composition of votes, with batches starting only with either depth 0 votes or votes without left neighbor). However, obtaining such permutation in MPC is non-trivial, and likely will produce at least an undesirable log⁡(m)\log(m)log(m) overhead.

chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/common-const.title: Less than
chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/common-const.body:
Less than
This functionality returns a shared bit [ab][a [ab] for two shared values [a],[b][a], [b][a],[b].
We use three interval tests:
[z]=[b−ap2],[x]=[ap2],[y]=[b>p2][z] = [b-a  \frac{p}{2}][z]=[b−a2p​],[x]=[a2p​],[y]=[b>2p​] and output
([z]∧[x])∨([z]∧[y])∨(¬[z]∧[x]∧[y])=[z(x+y)+(1−z)xy]([z] \wedge [x]) \vee ([z] \wedge [y]) \vee(\neg [z] \wedge [x] \wedge [y]) = [z(x+y) + (1-z)xy]([z]∧[x])∨([z]∧[y])∨(¬[z]∧[x]∧[y])=[z(x+y)+(1−z)xy].

chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/common-const.title: Inversion
chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/common-const.body:
Inversion
This functionality takes a shared value [x][x][x] and returns an uniform random sharing of x−1x^{-1}x−1. We will denote it as [x−1][x^{-1}][x−1]. It is implemented as follows:

[r∈RFp][r \in_R \mathbb{F_p}][r∈R​Fp​].
Open [rx][rx][rx].
[x−1]=(rx)−1[r][x^{-1}] = (rx)^{-1} [r][x−1]=(rx)−1[r].

chapter-4-protocol/client.html.title: Client side
chapter-4-protocol/client.html.body:
Client side
Stub
This describes possible ways of inputting the required information into MPC. There are various tradeoffs available. We will need to choose one at some point, but currently are uncertain on this.
Client, of course, needs to provide an aforementioned proof of validity of the vote. But this vote also needs to be encrypted in some way. This way, ideally, should be

MPC-friendly in a sense that it is easy to decrypt.
Proof-friendly in a sense the witness of decryption is easy to produce in MPC.

Separate parties handoff
This is the simplest way to implement, and, arguably, it also incurs minimal computation for MPC. It, however, leads to a nnn-times blowup in both bandwidth and client-side work.
This works as follows - the user creates their shares client-side, and encrypts them separately with public keys of the parties using some SNARK-friendly way (say, elliptic ElGamal over the JubJub curve + MiMC). They publish the encrypted shares. The MPC side then produces the proof of decryption (which is easy to do because the parts of the witness can be constructed by the individual parties).
Shared private key
In this case, the client encrypts the vote only once, and MPC does the proof of the decryption. It is less efficient in terms of the MPC work, but can be improved a bit by using different circuit for El Gamal decryption - doing nnn separate scalar products with shares of the private key. This admits an efficient witness, because the scalar multiplication part of the witness is now held by the parties separately.
Outsourcing KZG input
This version is ideal from the MPC standpoint, but puts a very heavy computational load on the client.
In this case, the client does 2 transactions for each vote. First one is "register", which sets an id of the vote, which we will denote as iii, and we will now assume that the vote structure has the length of kkk field elements. Increase it by 111, by adding the blinding factor vote.advice.
The second one consists of the encryption of the vote (in some MPC-friendly way), the proof of validity, and the following additional data:

The KZG commitment ∑k−1t=0vote.i ∗Lki+t+vote.advice ∗T\underset{t=0}{\overset{k-1}\sum} \text{vote.i }* L_{ki+t} + \text{vote.advice }*Tt=0∑k−1​​vote.i ∗Lki+t​+vote.advice ∗T.
The proof that this KZG commitment corresponds to the decryption of the encrypted vote.

This, of course, allows to circumvent all of the proving work on the MPC side - it can just add up KZG commitments, creating the input column to the PlonK. The proof on the client side, on the other hand, is extremely heavy because it requires multi-scalar multiplication over non-native field. It remains to be seen whether it is possible to somehow tackle this issue.

chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/beaver-tripl.title: Beaver triples
chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/beaver-tripl.body:
Beaver triples
The additions of linearly shared values (and generally any linear operations) can be done locally, without any interaction between the parties: ​[x+y]=[x]+[y][x + y] = [x] + [y][x+y]=[x]+[y].
Multiplication requires interaction. The following fundamental construction by Beaver allows to do it provided we have a certain precomputed data:
Assume that we have a precomputed triple of shared values ​[a],[b],[c][a], [b], [c][a],[b],[c], satisfying the following properties:

ab=cab = cab=c
a,ba, ba,b and sharings of all three are distributed uniformly randomly independently for all parties.

Then, the following construction allows us to sacrifice this pre-computed triple to multiply two shared elements:
open: (x+a),(y+b)\text{open: } (x+a), (y+b)open: (x+a),(y+b)
[xy]=(x+a)[y]+(y+b)[x]−(x+a)(y+b)+[c][xy] = (x+a)[y] + (y+b)[x] - (x+a)(y+b) + [c][xy]=(x+a)[y]+(y+b)[x]−(x+a)(y+b)+[c]
It is easy to see (by direct inspection), that what we've obtained is, indeed, the sharing of xyxyxy. ​
The triple must be "sacrificed", i.e. never used again anywhere, so that openings of x+ax+ax+a and y+by+by+b leak no information.
The problem of actually constructing Beaver triples is a known cryptographic problem. It is isolated and out of scope of our research, so we treat Beaver triples as an idealized functionality.

chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/common-const.title: Random number bitwise sharing
chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/common-const.body:
Random number bitwise sharing
This functionality, denoted as [r∈RFp]B[r \in_R \mathbb{F}_p]_B[r∈R​Fp​]B​, generates a (uniformly randomly shared) bit decomposition of a (uniformly random) value in Fp\mathbb{F}_pFp​.
This is typically done in precomputation phase, and implemented as follows:

Set l=⌈log⁡2(p)⌉l = \lceil \log_2(p)\rceill=⌈log2​(p)⌉, obtain a random bitstring [a]B[a]_B[a]B​ of length lll via [ai∈R{0,1}][a_i \in_R \{0,1\}][ai​∈R​{0,1}].
Calculate [aBp][a [aB​p] and open it, if it is 111, output [a]B[a]_B[a]B​, otherwise repeat process.

chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/common-const.title: Interval test
chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/common-const.body:
Interval test
This functionality, denoted as [axb][a [axb] tests whether [x][x][x] lives in a public interval (a;b)(a; b)(a;b).
It is implemented as follows:

[r∈RFp]B[r \in_R \mathbb{F}_p]_B[r∈R​Fp​]B​, calculate [r]=∑l−1i=02i[ri][r] = \underset{i=0}{\overset{l-1}\sum}2^i [r_i][r]=i=0∑l−1​​2i[ri​]
Open [r+x][r+x][r+x], and denote a′=(r+x)−b;b′=(r+x)−aa' = (r + x) - b;  b' = (r + x) - aa′=(r+x)−b;b′=(r+x)−a
Now, we output ([a′Br]∧[rBb′])∨([a′+pBr]∧[rBb′+p])([a' ([a′B​r]∧[rB​b′])∨([a′+pB​r]∧[rB​b′+p])

Here, some of the public terms are trivial automatically, and do not need to be calculated (any checks that are out of the range [0..p−1][0 .. p-1][0..p−1]).

chapter-1-overview/design-considerations.title: Design considerations
chapter-1-overview/design-considerations.body:
Design considerations
There are few principles we use when translating the system to MPC, and few necessary changes to the standard MACI.

Moving things that are provable client-side to the client. In standard MACI, the server decrypts all messages, and processes them, checking correctness as a first step. Computations in MPC are much costlier, so we opt to push a lot of work to the client side. Specifically, the encrypted message is accompanied with a Groth16 zk-proof, which validates that the message:
Decrypts to a well-formed vote
The signature is correct
The vote vector is correct for this user
Keychange is correct




Parallel processing. The main bottleneck in the arithmetic MPC is round-complexity, therefore normal sequential processing of votes 1-by-1 is inefficient. Instead, we use oblivious stable sort by key as a main primitive, and custom permutation arguments for the proof.
As a funny byproduct, the behavior differs from standard MACI in a subtle way (which doesn't break coercion-resistance). Namely, it is possible to "time travel" - for example, the sequence of keychanges K2→K3K_2 \rightarrow K_3K2​→K3​, K1→K2K_1 \rightarrow K_2K1​→K2​ ​ correctly changes they key from ​K1K_1K1​ to K3K_3K3​. The keychanges from a single key are still ordered by timestamp, and only the first one is valid, so the normal coercion-resistance mechanism works.

Keychange non-collision. For our approach, it is very convenient that the graph of all key-changes of an individual user is a forest (disjoint collection of trees). We enforce it in a following way:

First of all, our keys are not actual keys, and better thought of as "vote identifiers", any vote contains normal signature of a public key, and the identifier​ KKK.
Initial identifier is still set to be ​Kinit=PuserK_{\text{init}}=P_{\text{user}}Kinit​=Puser​.
On a keychange, new key K′K'K′​ must be obtained as K′=Hash(K,R)K' = \text{Hash}(K, R)K′=Hash(K,R)​, where KKK​ is an old key, and RRR is supplied by the user. This is checked in the zk-proof provided by the client, and guarantees the impossibility of reaching the same key from two different keys, provided that we use a collision resistant hash function.


For optimisation reasons, we might require the voter to send a pair of transactions: first one registering vote id, and second one with the vote. This is done to enable the following trick: user sends both their part of the PlonK input commitment, and encrypted vote which contains their input, with the proof that these two pieces are in accord. Then, in MPC we do not need to provide decryption witness and can just use the sum of user commitments as an input column.


The extensive discussion on this is here

chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/common-const.title: Random bits
chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/common-const.body:
Random bits
This functionality produces a random element [x]∈Fp[x] \in \mathbb{F}_p[x]∈Fp​, with x∈{0,1}x \in \{0, 1\}x∈{0,1}, uniformly distributed, and its shares also uniformly randomly distributed.
It is denoted as [x∈R{0,1}][x \in_R \{0,1\}][x∈R​{0,1}], and can be pre-computed in the offline phase (so during the computation we assume that we have a collection of random bits).
The method of constructing such xxx is as follows:

Pick a canonical way of constructing a square root over Fp\mathbb{F}_pFp​, say, be requiring t∈{0,...,p−12}\sqrt t \in \{0, ..., \frac{p-1}{2}\}t​∈{0,...,2p−1​}.
Produce a random shared element [r∈RFp][r \in_R \mathbb{F}_p][r∈R​Fp​].
Calculate r2r^2r2 and open it. If it is 000, start over (this happens with negligible probability).
Set [x]=1+[r]/r22[x] = \frac{1 + [r] / \sqrt{r^2}}{2}[x]=21+[r]/r2​​

chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/common-const.title: Bit decomposition
chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/common-const.body:
Bit decomposition
Previous constructions were intentionally circumventing bit-decomposition protocol, as it is more heavy than any of them. However, sometimes bit decomposition is necessary.
This functionality takes a shared value [x][x][x] and produces a shared bitstring [x]B[x]_B[x]B​.

[r∈RFp]B[r \in_R \mathbb{F}_p]_B[r∈R​Fp​]B​, calculate [r]=∑li=02iri[r] = \underset{i=0}{\overset{l}\sum}2^ir_i[r]=i=0∑l​​2iri​
Open b=(x+r)modpb = (x+r) \mod pb=(x+r)modp, denote bib_ibi​ its bit decomposition. Denote bi′b'_ibi′​ the bit decomposition of p+bp + bp+b.
Calculate [t]=[r≤b][t] = [r \leq b][t]=[r≤b].
Set [qi]=[t]bi′+[1−t]bi[q_i] = [t] b'_i + [1-t] b_i[qi​]=[t]bi′​+[1−t]bi​
[x]B=[q]B−[r]B[x]_B = [q]_B - [r]_B[x]B​=[q]B​−[r]B​ //obtained using bitstring subtraction

chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/common-const.title: Round-efficient multiplication
chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/common-const.body:
Round-efficient multiplication
This functionality (which we denote as normal multiplication ∏ni=1xi\underset{i=1}{\overset{n}\prod}x_ii=1∏n​​xi​ and always use in case we need to multiply >2>2>2 factors) computes the product of nnn elements. It works as follows:

[ri∈RFp], for i∈{0..n}[r_i \in_R \mathbb{F}_p], \text{ for }i \in \{0 .. n\}[ri​∈R​Fp​], for i∈{0..n}
[si]=[ri/ri−1] for i∈{1..n}[s_i] = [r_i / r_{i-1}] \text{ for }i \in \{1 .. n\}[si​]=[ri​/ri−1​] for i∈{1..n} //this can be computed in the offline phase
[yi]=[si][xi] for i∈{1..n}[y_i] = [s_i] [x_i] \text{ for }i \in \{1 .. n\}[yi​]=[si​][xi​] for i∈{1..n}
Open yiy_iyi​, calculate Y=∏ni=1yiY = \underset{i=1}{\overset{n}\prod}y_iY=i=1∏n​​yi​.
Output Y[r0rn−1]Y [r_0 r_n^{-1}]Y[r0​rn−1​]

This also allows to compute running product x1;x1x2;...;x1x2...xnx_1; x_1 x_2; ...; x_1 x_2 ... x_nx1​;x1​x2​;...;x1​x2​...xn​ in one go using the same method: in step 4 we compute all Yk=∏ki=1yiY_k = \underset{i=1}{\overset{k}\prod}y_iYk​=i=1∏k​​yi​, and then calculate Yk[r0rk−1]Y_k[r_0 r_k^{-1}]Yk​[r0​rk−1​]

chapter-3-subprotocols/shared-decrypt.ht.title: Shared decryption
chapter-3-subprotocols/shared-decrypt.ht.body:
Shared decryption
This subprotocol implements the MPC of an ElGamal scheme.
We use the following simple version of ElGamal:
The cleartext MMM is an element of the cryptographic group EEE with qqq points with DDH assumption, X=xGX = xGX=xG is a public key of a recipient. Then, sender creates the cyphertext (C=M+kP,K=kG)(C = M + kP, K = kG)(C=M+kP,K=kG), where k∈RZqk \in_R \mathbb{Z}_qk∈R​Zq​.
In order to decrypt, the recipient calculates M=C−xKM = C - xKM=C−xK.

Now, consider the recipient which is an MPC with nnn parties, and assume they have a Zq\mathbb{Z}_qZq​-shared private key [x][x][x]. Naturally, they can obtain the shared-over-group value [M]E=C−[x]K[M]_E = C - [x]K[M]E​=C−[x]K.
As a last step, they use conversion described in sharing over groups to obtain coordinate-wise representation of the message MMM.

chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/common-const.title: Equality test
chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/common-const.body:
Equality test
This functionality, denoted as [a=b][a=b][a=b] returns a shared bit corresponding to the equality property. We consider only the particular case where the RHS is zero, because general equality is implemented trivially as [a−b=0][a-b=0][a−b=0].
To obtain [x=0][x=0][x=0] we do the following:

[r∈RFp]B[r \in_R \mathbb{F}_p]_B[r∈R​Fp​]B​
Compute [r]=∑l−1i=02i[ri][r] = \underset{i=0}{\overset{l-1}\sum} 2^i[r_i][r]=i=0∑l−1​​2i[ri​]
Open [x+r][x+r][x+r], denote as bib_ibi​ its bit decomposition.
Set [qi]=bi?[ri]:(1−[ri])[q_i] = b_i ? [r_i] : (1-[r_i])[qi​]=bi​?[ri​]:(1−[ri​])
[x=0]=∨l−1i=0[qi][x=0] = \underset{i=0}{\overset{l-1}\vee}[q_i][x=0]=i=0∨l−1​​[qi​]

It is important to note that because rrr is uniformly distributed in Fp\mathbb{F}_pFp​, revealing r+xr+xr+x doesn't leak any information about xxx.

chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/common-const.title: Sharing over groups
chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/common-const.body:
Sharing over groups
We do not know the exact reference for this, but the idea is quite straightforward. Suppose we have a group GGG of order qqq.
We call a group sharing (and denote [X]G[X]_G[X]G​) the linear sharing over this group. The additions and multiplications by public scalar in Zq\mathbb{Z}_qZq​ work as expected. Provided we have Beaver triples over Zq\mathbb{Z}_qZq​ we can use them to multiply elements by Zq\mathbb{Z}_qZq​-shared scalars.
Finally, provided we have a pairing G1×G2→GmG_1 \times G_2 \rightarrow G_mG1​×G2​→Gm​, we can also pair shared elements using Beaver triples.
This is heavily used in a recent work https://eprint.iacr.org/2021/1530 on Collaborative SNARKs, which exploits this fact to efficiently prove SNARKs in MPC.

In a situation where GGG is a group of points of an elliptic curve over Fp\mathbb{F}_pFp​ (which we assume is given in Edwards form and has closed addition formulas), it makes sense to discuss the type conversions:

In order to go from [X]G[X]_G[X]G​ to coordinate sharing, we pick each player's elliptic share XiX_iXi​ and interpret it is an individual variable (0,0,...,Xi,...,0)(0, 0, ..., X_i, ..., 0)(0,0,...,Xi​,...,0). These can be converted into coordinate form trivially (because they are not shared), and then added up using addition formulas.  The addition can be done in a small number of rounds using technique similar to unbounded multiplication fan-in, but we are not certain whether this actually gives a speedup in practice.

We never require the reverse type conversion, but it can also, theoretically, be done, by all players except player 0 choosing random elements XiX_iXi​, then subtracting them from a coordinate-shared element XXX, and, finally, revealing their shares of X−∑i>0XiX - \underset{i>0}\sum X_iX−i>0∑​Xi​ to the player 0.


The first conversion is useful for the El Gamal shared decryption.

chapter-5-random-ideas/keychain.html.title: Keychain
chapter-5-random-ideas/keychain.html.body:
Key chain
this is Yar's suggestion on ensuring that the key can not be sold
it is not currently incorporated into the rest of the system; significant review might be required
also likely applicable for normal MACI
Idea:
Let's organize private keys in chains of unknown length. As a simplest example: let HHH be some hash function, and use H(x)H(x)H(x) as a public key corresponding to a private key xxx. Then, let's say that yyy dominates xxx if we know such integer k>0k>0k>0 that H∘k(y)=xH^{\circ k}(y) = xH∘k(y)=x.
If we have provided the coercing party with a private key, it can not be known for sure whether this private key is dominated (whether it actually has a known preimage).
Then, let's give a dominating public key yyy ability to "cancel" public key xxx in our voting system (in a simplest version, this can even be used instead of keychanges). This not only gives non-coercibility, but also prevents key selling.
I.e., simplest (not very efficient) MACI-style voting system works like this: there is an initial registry of keys of height 000; users send their (encrypted) transactions, which include signatures with keys of arbitrary non-negative height kkk (possibly with zk-proof that the result of kkk hashes gives the key from the registry to prevent DoS). Server nullifies all dominated votes and sums up all non-dominated.
Algorithm therefore becomes:

sort transaction list TTT by a 2-wide register: ASC by user, DESC by height, DESC by timestamp
add padding element with idx 0
for transaction with index i∈1..Ni \in 1..Ni∈1..N add field as follows T[i].valid=(T[i].user!=T[i−1].user)T[i].valid = (T[i].user != T[i - 1].user)T[i].valid=(T[i].user!=T[i−1].user)
aggregate "valid" transactions into voting result

This seems to not require security deposit.

chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/linear-shari.title: Linear sharing
chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/linear-shari.body:
Linear sharing
There are two main approaches to the multi-party computation: garbling circuits and linear sharing. Garbling circuits are not viable in our case (they are 2 party), so we use the linear sharing approach. There are few different flavors of the sharing; we use SPDZ, but most of ours constructions probably can be switched to other kinds of linear sharing.
We work over a prime field of large size, denoted ​Fp\mathbb{F}_pFp​.
Linearly shared variable is represented as ​[x][x][x], which denotes the share xix_ixi​ for a party iii (i.e. any formula involving shared values is read by substituting [x][x][x] by xix_ixi​ for a point of view of iii-th party).
In SPDZ, the "true" value xxx is reconstructed just as a sum of shares x=∑n−1i=0xix = \underset{i=0}{\overset{n-1}{\sum}} x_ix=i=0∑n−1​​xi​.
The value can be "opened", which means that the parties reveal their shares to eachother. It can be done either with or without first commiting to the share - in the latter case, the parties which open their share later can, potentially, change the result. We always assume that the open functionality does not commit to the shares, unless stated explicitly.
In SPDZ, each shared value ​[x][x][x] is normally accompanied with the independently shared value [λx][\lambda x][λx]​, for a globally chosen unique shared MAC key [λ][\lambda][λ]. This is used for the integrity checks. We do not use it in the current protocol because we need to produce a zk-proof anyways, and integrity validation does not work in case all parties do collude.
We do it (but do not spell it out explictly) in computations in the offline phase, to ensure that every part of correlated randomness is distributed as required.
Public values can be multiplied by shared values naively: y×[x]=y[x]y \times [x] = y[x]y×[x]=y[x], and public value yyy can be turned into the shared value by setting y0=yy_0 = yy0​=y, yi=0 for i>0y_i = 0 \text{ for } i>0yi​=0 for i>0 . This conversion is assumed in the cases where public value needs to be treated as shared (say, they are added).

chapter-3-subprotocols/obliv-sort.html.title: Oblivious sort by key
chapter-3-subprotocols/obliv-sort.html.body:
Oblivious sort by key
We describe here briefly the construction of Hamada et al. The only difference with it is that we suggest using Laud's efficient oblivious random permutation protocol instead of the one used in the original paper.
The sort here is, actually, a stable radix sort.
Sort by revealed key
This is a subprotocol, which picks an array of (key, value) pairs ([Ki],[Vi])([K_i],[V_i])([Ki​],[Vi​]) and sorts it by key, but leaks keys in process.
It works as follows:

Do oblivious random permutation.
Reveal keys and sort the array by them.

Stable sort by rrr-bit register
Consider a short key of size rrr bits. We will now sort an array of size mmm by this key.

For each iii, form an indicator vector Pˉi\bar P_iPˉi​ of size 2r2^r2r, where [Pij]:=[Ki=j][P_{ij}] := [K_i = j][Pij​]:=[Ki​=j].
Form also a vector Sˉi\bar S_iSˉi​, such that [Sij]=[Kij]=∑2rs>jPis[S_{ij}] = [K_i j}{\overset{2^r}\sum} P_{is}[Sij​]=[Ki​j]=s>j∑2r​​Pis​.
For each iii from 111 to mmm, calculate the running sum [Qˉi]=∑i−1k=0[Pˉk][\bar Q_i] = \underset{k=0}{\overset{i-1}\sum} [\bar P_k][Qˉ​i​]=k=0∑i−1​​[Pˉk​]. This counts the amount of different values of the key up to the point iii.
Calculate the reveal key [Ri]=∑2r−1k=0([QikPik]+[QmkSik])[R_i] = \underset{k=0}{\overset{2^r - 1}{\sum}}([Q_{ik} P_{ik}] + [Q_{mk} S_{ik}])[Ri​]=k=0∑2r−1​​([Qik​Pik​]+[Qmk​Sik​]). This calculates the amount of key values less than the current key value, plus the amount of the key values equal to the current key value before this element - which is exactly the position where the element should land in a sorted array.
Engage in the revealing sort subprotocol, using RiR_iRi​ as keys.

Stable sort by key
The stable sort by key works by splitting key into rrr-sized registers, and then engaging in a stable sort by registers.
Complexity
Steps of one instance of stable sort by rrr-bit register involve:

6 online rounds for equality test.
0 rounds
0 rounds
1 round for multiplication
n rounds for oblivious permutation and 1 round to open RiR_iRi​

Therefore, it takes 8+n8+n8+n rounds. The size of rrr-bit registers is, therefore, a tradeoff between (exponential) blowup in offline computation and amount of invocations of the stable sort by register.

chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/common-const.title: Bitwise less-than
chapter-2-preliminaries/MPC/common-const.body:
Bitwise less-than
Here and after we denote as [a]B[a]_B[a]B​ the bitstring representation (i.e. sequence of shared bits correspondings to the binary decomposition of aaa). Our purpose is, for two bitstrings, to compute the bit [aBb][a [aB​b].

[ci]=[ai]⊕[bi]=[ai]+[bi]−2[aibi][c_i] = [a_i] \oplus [b_i] = [a_i] + [b_i] - 2[a_i b_i][ci​]=[ai​]⊕[bi​]=[ai​]+[bi​]−2[ai​bi​]
[di]=∨l−1s=ics[d_i] = \underset{s=i}{\overset{l-1}{\vee}}c_s[di​]=s=i∨l−1​​cs​ // using prefix OR.
[ei]=[di]−[di+1][e_i] = [d_i] - [d_{i+1}][ei​]=[di​]−[di+1​] for ili il, [el−1]=[dl−1][e_{l-1}] = [d_{l-1}][el−1​]=[dl−1​]
[aBb]=∑l−1i=0[eibi][a [aB​b]=i=0∑l−1​​[ei​bi​]

It is easy to see by direct inspection: di=0d_i = 0di​=0 up to (counting from the most significant bit, l−1l-1l−1) the first different bit, and from it equals 111. Therefore, eie_iei​ equals 111 exactly in the the most significant different bit, and, hence, ∑l−1i=0[eibi]\underset{i=0}{\overset{l-1}\sum} [e_i b_i]i=0∑l−1​​[ei​bi​] computes 000 if this bit is 000 in bbb, and 111 if this bit is 111 in bbb. The only remaining case is if a=ba = ba=b, in which case all the variables in these equations are 000, as it should be.

chapter-4-protocol/server-mpc.html.title: Server side MPC
chapter-4-protocol/server-mpc.html.body:
Server side MPC
Here, we describe the bulk of the procedure. We have separated the witness generation for the zk-proof audit to the separate subsection, because it is logically independent.
Input
Server has a fixed public key PPP in some cryptographic group, implemented over Fq\mathbb{F}_qFq​. We will assume it is JubJub curve in what follows, but other options are available, depending on the used proof system.
The corresponding private key [p][p][p] is linearly shared.
On-chain, the sequence of encrypted votes is published; each vote is accompanied with a zk-proof of its validity predicate. The form of encryption is currently discussed, there are few options (encrypting all with El Gamal, using El Gamal for symmetric key and MiMC for the vote encryption, encrypting shares separately, or potentially adding supplementary advice simplifying data transfer to the main circuit) with different tradeoffs w.r.t. MPC work, witness size and client proving work, respectively. This is TBD, we continue this discussion in client side subsection.
The individual (decrypted) vote v consists of the following data:
v.user - an unique id of the sender in the global registry.
v.from - a 254-bit key (from which this tx attempts to switch)
v.to - a 254-bit key (to which this tx attempts to switch)
v.votes[n] - a vote vector
v.depth - a number in range 0..2128−10..2^{128}-10..2128−1
The validity predicate (which needs to be proven client side), says that the vote decrypts to the aforementioned data, and, moreover

Prover controls cryptographic identity of v.user.
v.to == 0 or v.votes[n] == 0 (either tx is a key-switch, or a vote).
(votes, user) pair satisfies the voting rules.
Depth satisfies range constraints.
Knowledge of such R, that(v.to == 0) or v.to == Hash(v.depth, v.from, R).
(v.depth > 0) or (v.from == init_key[v.user]), where init_key is a set of public initial keys of the users.

The requirement 555 is such that no valid keyswitches should lead to the same v.to key from different states (together with large key size to prevent hash collisions).
The requirement 666 constrains the initial key if we are at depth 0.
We also refer to an order of a vote in a list of all votes as v.timestamp, and also add a field v.invalid = 0.
Shared decryption phase
 We assume that all of the data is properly constrained (via public checking of validity predicate proof). After this phase (which depends on the encryption implementation) we assume that decrypted votes are all linearly shared between parties, and proceed to the main part of the protocol.
We put them in the shared array vote.
Main computation
Our main idea is to only use sorting + local operations for round optimization purposes. During the computation, we will mainly sort the main array vote (and pretend that operations done are in-place to simplify the notation, but we will need some of the computation trace later to construct the witness).
One should imagine the set of key-switches of a particular user as a set of trees (starting either from an initial key or from depth > 0). We will also require that every key-switch increases the depth by 1. Note, that because of the non-collision property it should not be possible to have the same v.to field with different v.from or v.depth. Therefore, this graph, indeed, will not have cycles.
0. Depth compression
In this round, we discard all votes with v.depth > total_vote_count. This is done to aggressively optimize amount of sorting rounds. Such votes had no chance to be valid anyways, and we believe an adversarial player can not reveal any useful information using this. In what follows, total amount of votes after this reduction is m.
1. Key compression
This round has two purposes: first, we make the key-size smaller to simplify radix sort, and, second, we ensure that there are no coinciding keys from different users. It is done as follows:
Every vote is duplicated, with an additional field v.ext set to 0 and 1 respectively, we refer to this array as vote2. For an extended vote, denote v.main_key() = v.ext*v.from + (1-v.ext)v.to
v in vote2 is sorted (in order of priority) by v.user > v.main_key().
Introduce an array jump of the same size, set jump[0] = 0 and for i from 1 to m-1:
jump[i] = 
(vote2[i].main_key() != vote2[i-1].main_key()) or (vote2[i].user != vote2[i-1].user)
Calculate the running sum q[i]=∑ij=0jump[i]\text{q[i]} = \underset{j=0}{\overset i \sum}\text{jump[i]}q[i]=j=0∑i​​jump[i]. This running sum is constant over the votes that are from the same user and have the coinciding main_key.
Now, we will set for each i:
vote2[i].from = vote2[i].ext * q[i] + (1-vote2[i].ext) * vote2[i].from
vote2[i].to   = (1 - vote2[i].ext) * q[i] + vote2[i].ext * vote2[i].to
which sets the key by which it was sorted to the compressed version.
Now, we order the vote2 back by timestamp (using revealing sort), and then merge the pairs back:

Reveal the vote2[2*i].ext field; if it is 1, do nothing, if it is 0, swap this element with vote2[2*i+1].
Set vote[i].from = vote2[2*i].from; vote[i].to = vote[2*i+1].to.

This replaces each key with an element of size no more than ⌈log⁡(m)⌉\lceil \log(m) \rceil⌈log(m)⌉, in such a way that:

Same keys of the same user are mapped in the same compressed versions.
There are no other collisions; in particular same keys of different users are mapped to different compressed versions // this never happens normally because initial keys are different, but might be a result of a deliberate attack (an attacker could send a "hanging" vote of depth > 0 with arbitrary from key).

1. Initial sort
The votes are sorted (in order of priority) by  v.from > v.timestamp (by which they were already sorted, so no additional action is required because sort is stable).
After this, we set vote.invalid = (vote[k-1].from == vote[k].from) for all k>0.
After this round, all votes that have a particular "from" key after the first attempt of using such "from" key will be invalidated. Note that if the first keyswitch turns out to be invalid later (due to the depth requirement), it will also invalidate further valid keyswitch.
The result of the round will be that the tree valid key-switches is now a set of linear paths ("bamboos").
2. The main cycle
Denote d=⌈log⁡(m)⌉d = \lceil \log(m) \rceild=⌈log(m)⌉. We will need ddd rounds of sorting.
Denote v.odd(r) = v.depth&1
Denote v.sort_key(r) = v.odd(r) ? v.from : v.to
On r-th round:
Sort v in vote by (in order of priority) v.invalid > v.sort_key(r).
Now, 
for i from 1 to m-1:
    if vote[i].odd(r):
        if (vote[i-1].depth + 1This results in all votes of odd depth checking whether their left neighbor has the same to field as they have from,  and whether depth actually increases by 1. Then, we basically "merge" them, by setting the left neighbor's to field and the vote vector to the to field and the vote vector of the composition, and then invalidating the odd vote.
The votes of odd depth which do not find their left neighbor are invalidated without further actions.
Note: to counter the quirky behavior with "time travel", mentioned in the introduction, one needs to add to the check the part ...& (vote[i-1].timestamp . This is not hard to do if needed.
3. Final calculation
At this point, we just need to sum vote[i].votes * (1-vote[i].invalid) over the array to get voting results. In the next part, we will describe the slight modifications needed to produce an auditing zk-proof.
Complexity
Concrete estimates here are hard, and they probably will depend on the size of the vote vector; one methodology could be estimating total amount of radix sorts that we need to perform (assuming constant register size). Practically, this will be traded off against RAM size of the server machines, but it at least gives an estimate. We will also roughly estimate from above the size of user_id field as d=⌈log⁡(m)⌉d = \lceil \log(m) \rceild=⌈log(m)⌉.

In compression phase, we need to sort an array of size 2m2m2m by a key of total size 254+d254+d254+d, and then do one additional revealing sort of size 2m2m2m (which we will promptly ignore in this calculation).
After the compression phase, the fields from and to also have a size ddd. Initial sort, thus, is a sort of an array of size mmm by a key of size ddd.
Main phase involves ddd rounds in which we sort by d+1d+1d+1-bit sized key (additional bit is for invalid bit flag).

Denoting by rrr the radix sort register bitsize, we need to do (254+d)/r(254+d)/r(254+d)/r radix sorts of size 2m2m2m, and d(d+2)/rd(d+2)/rd(d+2)/r radix sorts of size mmm.
Round complexity, thus, is (8+n)(256+2d)d/r+d×local_ops(8+n)(256+2d)d/r + d \times \text{local\_ops}(8+n)(256+2d)d/r+d×local_ops, but agressive optimization for rrr is bounded by the exponential blowup in memory requirement.

chapter-3-subprotocols/obliv-permute.htm.title: Oblivious random permutation
chapter-3-subprotocols/obliv-permute.htm.body:
Oblivious random permutation
The procedure
This is the main building block of the oblivious sort. We briefly describe here the recent construction of Peeter Laud; it specifically requires SPDZ, so it might need to be replaced in case one wants to use different sharing scheme.
For each pair of parties i,ji, ji,j, we need to precompute the following data Xi,XjX_i, X_jXi​,Xj​ for each party:

The party iii picks a permutation π\piπ. Honest parties are assumed to pick it uniformly at random.
Pick a pair of random vectors xˉ,yˉ∈RFm\bar x, \bar y \in_R \mathbb{F}^mxˉ,yˉ​∈R​Fm. Set zˉ=π(xˉ)−yˉ\bar z = \pi(\bar x) - \bar yzˉ=π(xˉ)−yˉ​.
Set Xi=(π,zˉ)X_i = (\pi, \bar z)Xi​=(π,zˉ), Xj=(xˉ,yˉ)X_j = (\bar x, \bar y)Xj​=(xˉ,yˉ​).

In practice, this can be done in the offline phase in a few different ways.
Then, this precomputed data can be used to construct from a vector aˉj=(a1,...,am)j\bar a_j = (a_1, ..., a_m)_jaˉj​=(a1​,...,am​)j​ belonging to the jjj-th party a permuted vector [π(aˉ)]ij=([aπ(1)],...,[aπ(m)])ij[\pi(\bar a)]_{ij} = ([a_{\pi(1)}], ..., [a_{\pi(m)}])_{ij}[π(aˉ)]ij​=([aπ(1)​],...,[aπ(m)​])ij​ shared between iii and jjj in a following way:

jjj sends to iii the vector aˉ′=aˉ+xˉ\bar a' = \bar a + \bar xaˉ′=aˉ+xˉ
jjj sets π(aˉ)j=−yˉ\pi (\bar a)_j = -\bar yπ(aˉ)j​=−yˉ​
iii sets π(aˉ)i=π(aˉ′)−zˉ\pi(\bar a)_i = \pi(\bar a') - \bar zπ(aˉ)i​=π(aˉ′)−zˉ

Now, the oblivious random permutation protocol of a shared value [aˉ][\bar a][aˉ] is the following:
Repeat for each party iii:
Permute with πi\pi_iπi​ each of the shares aˉj\bar a_jaˉj​, setting the new shares value aˉj:=−yˉij\bar a_j := -\bar y_{ij}aˉj​:=−yˉ​ij​; set iii-th share to be the sum of discrepancies: aˉi:=∑j=1;j≠in[aˉij′]\bar a_i :=\overset{n}{\underset{j = 1; j \neq i}\sum}[\bar a'_{ij}]aˉi​:=j=1;j≠i∑​n​[aˉij′​].
This requires nnn rounds and total O(n2m)O(n^2 m)O(n2m) communication.
Active security
The protocol above is passively secure. The active check can be made post-factum:
to check that a pair of vectors aˉ,bˉ\bar a, \bar baˉ,bˉ are permutations of each other, we sample a random value ttt and check ∑1ai−t=∑1bi−t\sum \frac{1}{a_i - t} = \sum \frac{1}{b_i - t}∑ai​−t1​=∑bi​−t1​.
Offline phase
Offline phase can be done in various ways. We are currently planning to use butterfly network to apply a permutation π\piπ to a shared value [x][x][x] in the offline phase, but other approaches are also possible (mixnet approach might outperform butterfly network for large mmm), this is largely TBD.

chapter-5-random-ideas/game.html.title: Game-theoretic model
chapter-5-random-ideas/game.html.body:
Game-theoretic model:
Here, we are trying to provide the model for the coercing interaction. We make few simplifications: first, the vote utility of the seller is known to the buyer. Second, buyer has some prior assumption on the distribution of keychain height, we assume it to be uniformly random (for example, because this is our standard setup algorithm).
Utilities of the vote are denoted ubu_bub​ and usu_sus​.
Assume the following game with two parties:

Seller runs the setup phase protocol, outputting uniformly random number 0≤kN0  \leq k 0≤kN.

Buyer sets the price list: function p:{0..(N−1)}→R≥0p: \{0..(N-1)\} \rightarrow  \mathbb{R}_{\geq  0}p:{0..(N−1)}→R≥0​

Seller outputs the claimed height t≤kt \leq kt≤k.

If it outputs t=kt = kt=k, it gets p(k)p(k)p(k), and buyer gets ub−p(k)u_{b} - p(k)ub​−p(k), if it outputs tkttk, it gets p(t)+usp(t) + u_sp(t)+us​, and buyer gets −p(t)-p(t)−p(t).


First, it is easy to see whether seller defects on 3rd step or not. Clearly, if p(k)−max⁡tk[p(t)us]p(k) - \underset{tp(k)−tkmax​[p(t)us​], it is profitable to defect by outputting tkttk with maximal price, and otherwise, it is not profitable to defect.
Because we assume that the buyer has knowledge of usu_sus​, it can predict the optimal behavior of seller on the third step, lets optimize the price list.
Let's call the value kkk "bad" if p(k)−max⁡tk[p(t)us]p(k) - \underset{tp(k)−tkmax​[p(t)us​], and good otherwise. There is g≤Ng \leq Ng≤N good values. The prices in good values monotonously increase, with step at least usu_sus​. Bad values are never picked correctly, so their price can be safely set to 000 wlog.
Assuming we optimize for ggg good values, we can ensure that they grow exactly by usu_sus​ increments (which minimizes expected bribe over them), and ensure that expected bribe over bad values is 000 (by setting their price to 000 and moving them to the left of all good values): so, the optimal price list looks like p(N−α)=max⁡((g−α+1)us,0)p(N-\alpha) = \max((g-\alpha + 1)u_s, 0)p(N−α)=max((g−α+1)us​,0).
This gives the average bribe spending g(g+1)2Nus\frac{g(g+1)}{2N} u_s2Ng(g+1)​us​ with gN\frac{g}{N}Ng​ votes being purchased. This gives the cost of one vote g+12us\frac{g+1}{2} u_s2g+1​us​.
 Denote the advantage A=ub/usA = u_b / u_sA=ub​/us​ (if the buyer is going to buy votes it must have greater utility for them; practically speaking this advantage can be quite big if buyer is a resourceful party and seller is a small voter).
The buyer is willing to purchase votes at cost at most ubu_bub​. Solving g+12us=ub\frac{g+1}{2} u_s = u_b2g+1​us​=ub​ we get g=2A−1g = 2A - 1g=2A−1.
This means that at most 2A−1N\frac{2A - 1}{N}N2A−1​ votes will be purchased in this model.
Should we analyse it without prior distribution?
It is unclear for us what are the correct assumptions without buyer knowing the prior distribution of kkk - probably that of a repeated game. However, in practice the process of generating the key will eventually be bound to the modified  unconditional private key possession proof (see here Vitalik's description of such meatspace protocol for normal private keys), which fixes the distribution.
Can we do better with different distribution?
It is not exactly clear, but likely yes: while using non-uniform distribution on {0..N−1}\{0..N-1\}{0..N−1} means that the buyer can get an advantage by choosing a subset of size ggg with probability >g/N> g/N>g/N, this advantage likely will be offset by defections (for example, for slowly decreasing probability of obtaining kkk).
We did not work through details; nor did we consider more complex negotiation strategies.
